title: Internal usage of AdBlockPlus may expose PoC URLs to unknown third-parties

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
Hello HackerOne team,

this is probably going to be a *different* kind of report than what you are used to: it looks to me this is more of an internal, operational security best-practice that you may choose to follow.

This is something that's bugging me from January now, but it took me some time and thinking before reporting that because i wasn't completely sure of my initial intuition.

Anyway, since i keep getting supporting evidence, i decided it's finally time to reach out.

## Summary
Internal usage of AdBlockPlus by the HackerOne staff may inadvertently exposes PoC URLs or other sensitive information to unknown third-parties.

The problem is obviously broader than this and can easily encompass every single researcher who installed more or less exotic extensions in their browser (me as well), but ensuring that is a lot more difficult.

## Description

Back in January i reported a vulnerability to the ████ team via their managed program running on HackerOne at ██████████.

The associated PoC was meant to be a private webpage hosted by me that demonstrated the information leak i was reporting and the possibility to escalate that to an higher level.

During the triage process the status was changed to *Needs more info* by the H1 staff because the PoC wasn't running as expected and left a note that there was no way to confirm it: within the message, a screenshot of the error has been attached, showing the usage of the **AdBlock/AdBlockPlus** software.

Since the vulnerable endpoint was blocked due to being an ad-serving endpoint (!) i promptly replied to disable it and have the PoC running as expected, and not long after that i got a reply from the H1 staff stating they were able to reproduce it fine.

While waiting for reproduction i was monitoring my server's log for accesses to see if it got served fine, and this is where i noticed some *strange behavior kicking in*: the **Yandex search engine** was now accessing the PoC page from an IP belonging to the `5.*.*.*` range!

Unfortunately i don't have the January logs illustrating that endpoint being visited, but since i suspected AdBlock wasn't playing it right, i immediately renamed the page for one whole month or so, and the PoC has never been accessed anymore.

*I'm attaching a redacted screenshot from the original report that shows the page has been visited with ABP enabled.*

To ensure my suspicions were well founded i thought to setup some subdomains as *honey pots* for testing and decided to give it a go: 

- created `z.dudez.ninja` and `r34lz.dudez.ninja` subdomains
- installed AdBlockPlus in Chromium/Firefox
- browsed to both subdomains
- uninstalled AdBlockPlus
- (reinstalled my good old uBlock Origin)

Sure enough, just hours later i got the first hit asking for the `r34lz.dudez.ninja` subdomain, followed by the `z` one as well and to this day i still got hit by the crawlers there:
```
37.9.113.122 - - - "r34lz.dudez.ninja" [27/Jul/2018:21:24:26 +0000] -/- "GET /robots.txt HTTP/1.1" 404 178 "-" "Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; YandexBot/3.0; +http://yandex.com/bots)"
37.9.113.122 - - - "r34lz.dudez.ninja" [27/Jul/2018:21:24:30 +0000] -/- "GET / HTTP/1.1" 502 182 "-" "Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; YandexBot/3.0; +http://yandex.com/bots)"
..
5.255.253.8 - - - "r34lz.dudez.ninja" [15/Aug/2018:13:18:57 +0000] -/- "GET /robots.txt HTTP/1.1" 404 178 "-" "Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; YandexBot/3.0; +http://yandex.com/bots)"
95.108.181.100 - - - "r34lz.dudez.ninja" [15/Aug/2018:13:19:02 +0000] -/- "GET / HTTP/1.1" 502 182 "-" "Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; YandexBot/3.0; +http://yandex.com/bots)"
..
37.9.113.122 - - - "z.dudez.ninja" [15/Aug/2018:13:54:55 +0000] TLSv1.2/ECDHE-RSA-AES128-GCM-SHA256 "GET /robots.txt HTTP/1.1" 404 178 "-" "Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; YandexBot/3.0; +http://yandex.com/bots)"
37.9.113.122 - - - "z.dudez.ninja" [15/Aug/2018:13:54:59 +0000] TLSv1.2/ECDHE-RSA-AES128-GCM-SHA256 "GET / HTTP/1.1" 200 53 "-" "Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; YandexBot/3.0; +http://yandex.com/bots)"
```

I also read some articles in the past, hinting that ABP being a business will take advantage of its position (e.g. https://www.wired.com/2016/03/heres-how-that-adblocker-youre-using-makes-money/), in some way it looks like the browsing history is not that private after all.

As you noticed, although that was a managed program, i didn't disclose anything related to the report: if you need more information, such as the original report ID to ███ or whatever is missing feel free to ask, i'll be glad and more than willing to collaborate.

## Browsers Verified In
- n/a

## IP Address
- n/a

## Mitigation
If still in use and/or installed, i would encourage the H1 staff to stop using the AdBlock software and use [uBlock Origin](https://github.com/gorhill/uBlock) as a replacement.

## Impact

As we don't really know what kind of use AdBlock/AdBlockPlus is doing with the harvested data, hacker-submitted PoC and other sensitive information may be at risk of being indexed in some way.

additional_data.old_title: Internal usage of AdBlockPlus may exposes PoC URLs to unknown third-parties
additional_data.new_title: Internal usage of AdBlockPlus may expose PoC URLs to unknown third-parties

activities.message: Hi @dudez - thanks for bringing this to our attention. I'll discuss this with our IT team to see if we want to do anything about this. We'll get back to you in the next couple days!
activities.markdown_message: Hi @dudez - thanks for bringing this to our attention. I'll discuss this with our IT team to see if we want to do anything about this. We'll get back to you in the next couple days!

activities.message: Hi @dudez - just wanted to let you know that we've disabled the plugins from being installed on employee machines. We've provided an alternative for the time being. We'll continue to investigate this to resolve this. If you have any additional information that you can share with us, please let us know.
activities.markdown_message: Hi @dudez - just wanted to let you know that we've disabled the plugins from being installed on employee machines. We've provided an alternative for the time being. We'll continue to investigate this to resolve this. If you have any additional information that you can share with us, please let us know.

activities.message:
Hi @jobert, thank you much for getting back to me so fast, very much appreciated!
In case i'll be able to gather some more information i'll let you know.
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @jobert, thank you much for getting back to me so fast, very much appreciated!
In case i'll be able to gather some more information i'll let you know.

activities.message:
To enhance the initial information i wrote in the report, i have some more bits of information to add.

For the sake of completeness, i recall that after i manually setup the two subdomains for testing at my registrar and verified i received some hits, i removed the entries and setup a wildcard subdomain entry instead.

One other domain i tried to visit at the time was `test.dudez.ninja` and this received some hits as well and didn't really notice i got an hit by the YandexBot recently as well:
```
37.9.113.122 - - - "test.dudez.ninja" [28/Jul/2018:19:10:00 +0000] -/- "GET /robots.txt HTTP/1.1" 404 178 "-" "Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; YandexBot/3.0; +http://yandex.com/bots)"
37.9.113.122 - - - "test.dudez.ninja" [28/Jul/2018:19:10:03 +0000] -/- "GET / HTTP/1.1" 200 53 "-" "Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; YandexBot/3.0; +http://yandex.com/bots)"
```

Interestingly enough, i discovered this *got indexed and cached* by the Yandex search engine bots at some time, you can see that by browsing to Yandex.com and searching for `site:dudez.ninja` (see also the attached screenshot).

I'm still at a loss when it comes to determine the discriminant for which `test` got indexed and cached while `z` didn't, i can't remeber doing anything particular with any of these subdomains, but i find it intriguing nonetheless.

For the sake of completeness, i recall that after i manually setup the two subdomains for testing at my registrar and verified i received some hits, i removed the entries and setup a wildcard subdomain entry instead.

Interestingly enough, i discovered this got indexed and cached by the Yandex search engine bots at some time, you can see that by browsing to Yandex.com and searching for site:dudez.ninja (see also the attached screenshot).

I'm still at a loss when it comes to determine the discriminant for which test got indexed and cached while z didn't, i can't remeber doing anything particular with any of these subdomains, but i find it intriguing nonetheless.

activities.message: Hi @dudez - thanks again for this great report! We've looked into this and determined that us blocking the plugin from being installed is the only action item we're going to take right now. This was a great writeup and a pleasure to read through it, we'd love to see more from you in the future!
activities.markdown_message: Hi @dudez - thanks again for this great report! We've looked into this and determined that us blocking the plugin from being installed is the only action item we're going to take right now. This was a great writeup and a pleasure to read through it, we'd love to see more from you in the future!

activities.message: Hi @dudez - unfortunately, we've never recommended installing this plugin to our employees, nor did we provision this for them. Because of that we're going to award you with some great HackerOne swag instead of a bounty. The reason being that we can't pay for any malicious plugin that employees install at this point. The swag is for the amazing writeup. Thanks again!
activities.markdown_message: Hi @dudez - unfortunately, we've never recommended installing this plugin to our employees, nor did we provision this for them. Because of that we're going to award you with some great HackerOne swag instead of a bounty. The reason being that we can't pay for any malicious plugin that employees install at this point. The swag is for the amazing writeup. Thanks again!

activities.message:
Hi @jobert and HackerOne team, it was a pleasure to work with you all, thank you so much for the swag!

I can see the reasoning and i couldn't agree more with what you said, well done for taking actions so fast, and thank you much for your feedback, very appreciated!
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @jobert and HackerOne team, it was a pleasure to work with you all, thank you so much for the swag!

I can see the reasoning and i couldn't agree more with what you said, well done for taking actions so fast, and thank you much for your feedback, very appreciated!
